Posts.Content: Chuck biopsy T3a MRI and bone scan clear 18 April RP (nerve sparing on one side) with lymph lode dissection recovering well except for incontinence - but I can see patience and Kegels are needed now PSA July and review path with surgeon ~ 18 July fingers crossed Thanks Martyn
Posts.Title: prostate riddles

Posts.Content: I'm very fit and otherwise healthy 67 year old PSA 5.6 Gleason 4+3= 7 all 5 cores cancerous (right) 35% affected 3 cores cancerous (left) 10% affected waiting for MRI and bone scan Have run marathon and 3 half marathons since October Wouldnt I know if it had spread to my bones? Does bone scan pick up micro-metastasis? The dose is equivalent to 200 X rays! Is it really worthwhile? Is active surveillance an option?
Posts.Title: prostate riddles

Posts.Content: Chuck Thanks for that typo! it should say Gleason overall 3+4=7 (not 4+3) other info from biopsy - Right side 5/5 cores malignant 35% affected (3+4) Left side 3/5 cores malignant 10% affected(3+3) prostate volume 34ml I understand I wont get a staging report until the MRI (next week) PSA history 12/13 5.4 9/13 5.1 3/13 4.6 Martyn

Posts.Title: late elevation of PSA post surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Hi Martyn. Could you post your surgery pathology report findings and clinical staging? A confirmed rise in PSA can mean there is biochemical recurrence (BCR). This is from PSA produced by remaining healthy and/or cancerous prostate tissue left behind in the prostate bed or prostate-cancer cells elsewhere in the body (metastases). Some men with BCR go on to clinical disease recurrence in 5-8 years on the average. The usual treatment for BCR after surgery is radiation and possibly ADT (hormonal treatment), depending also on the suspected location of the PSA-producing tissue. Your urologist might refer you to a radiation oncologist IF the PSA upward trend is confirmed. Note that some men have an increasing PSA which then stabilizes and which doesn't require further treatment. The PSA level at which treatment is advised often depends on the number and type of adverse findings in the prostatectomy pathology report. Another factor is the rate of PSA rise. Newer PSMA-PET scans can help identify the location of the PSA-producing tissue. You and your doc will have more to go on after your next PSA test. You may want to speak to your uro about switching to a more sensitive PSA test (with 2 or 3 decimal places). This would make it possible to detect smaller changes: if the 0.2 was accurate, you may want to treat sooner than a 0.3 as measured by a one-decimal test. The right-most digit of any test is subject to inaccuracy and rounding. Keep us posted, please. Djin Hello Djin here is the Pathology report Macroscopy 1. Right no. of cores 5 2. Left no. of cores 5 Microscopy 1. (Right) Malignant No of cores with malignancy 5 tumour type: Adenocarcinoma Gleason 3+4 =7 PIN: Yes high grade Extra prostatic extension: No Extent of disease 35% 2. (Left) Malignant No of cores with malignancy 3 tumour type: Adenocarcinoma Gleason 3+3 =6 PIN: not seen Extra prostatic extension: No Extent of disease 10% summary Bilateral acinar adenocarcinoma overall Gleason score 3+4=7 The previous PSA (6/1 was <0.1 as were all previous tests 0.1 is the lower limit of testing available presently Thanks Martyn
Posts.Title: late elevation of PSA post surgery

Posts.Content: Hi, here is what you were asking for:- Path result (actual tumour) Gleason 3+4 with quite extensive tumour within the prostate stage pT3a with a positive radial margin on the right side
